ğŸ¢ Reading a `pt-query-digest` Report Without Losing Your Mind

02 May 2025

Youâ€™ve run pt-query-digest on your MySQL slow log. Now youâ€™re staring at a huge wall of text and wondering what to do with it. Hereâ€™s a practical breakdown of how to actually make sense of it â€” and fix slow queries that are dragging your database down.

1. Start with the Summary

Right at the top, youâ€™ll see something like:

# 1620 total queries
# 161 unique query patterns
# Time range: April 17â€“30, 2025
# Exec time avg: 22s
# Rows examined avg: 5.34M

What this tells you:

  • ğŸ’€ 22 seconds average execution time is alarmingly high.
  • ğŸ§ 5.34 million rows examined per query suggests indexing problems.

This section gives you a high-level health check of your workload. If it looks bad, it probably is.

2. Check the â€œProfileâ€ Section

The profile ranks queries by their total response time contribution.

# Rank Query ID                            Response time   Calls R/Call   V
# ==== =================================== =============== ===== ======== =
#    1 0x3A250BE32D8B29F0                  12340.7 33.8%    381  32.3906  0.42
#    2 0x4B3D9E81C5C0BC7B                   4313.9 11.8%     11 392.1736  0.01

How to read this:

  • ğŸ”¢ Rank: Based on total response time.
  • ğŸ§  Query ID: A fingerprint of the query (use it to search further down).
  • â± Response Time: How long this query took in total (and % of the total).
  • ğŸ” Calls: How many times this query ran.
  • âš ï¸ R/Call: Average time per execution â€” high values here are red flags.

3. Analyze Each Query Section

Scroll down for details on each top query. Youâ€™ll see blocks like:

# Query 1: 381 QPS, 12.34ks total, 33.8% of all time...
# Rank: 1
# Time range: 2025-04-17 to 2025-04-30
#
# Attribute    pct   total     min     max     avg     95%  stddev  median
# ============ === ======= ======= ======= ======= ======= ======= =======
# Count          23     381
# Exec time      33 12341s      1s    160s     32s     70s     24s     28s

Look for:

  • Execution time patterns â€” are they spiky?
  • High max or 95th percentile values? Thatâ€™s trouble.
  • Rows examined vs rows sent â€” are we reading too much and returning too little?

Then youâ€™ll find:

# Tables
SHOW TABLE STATUS FROM `database` LIKE 'users'\G
SHOW CREATE TABLE `database`.`users`\G
EXPLAIN SELECT * FROM users WHERE last_login < '2025-01-01' AND status = 'inactive'\G

Check:

  • Are there missing indexes?
  • Are we scanning the whole table (type: ALL)?
  • Is MySQL using a key (key: NULL means no index was used)?

4. Know the Red Flags ğŸš©

Watch out for:

  • â³ High average time per call with low execution count â†’ likely reporting/batch jobs.
  • ğŸ” High call counts with moderate execution time â†’ small optimizations can have huge payoff.
  • ğŸ“Š Rows examinedÂ Â» Rows sent â†’ indexing issues.
  • ğŸ” High lock time â†’ contention problems.
  • â— EXPLAIN mentions:
    • Using filesort
    • Using temporary
    • type: ALL
    • key: NULL
  • ğŸ§® Functions on indexed columns: DATE(created_at), MONTH(...), etc.

5. Prioritize Wisely

Focus on the queries that:

  • Take up >10% of total time
  • Are called hundreds or thousands of times
  • Examine huge numbers of rows unnecessarily
  • Lock up tables or create contention

6. Fix Them ğŸ› 

Once youâ€™ve picked your top offenders:

  • âœ… Add or adjust indexes (on WHERE, JOIN, GROUP BY columns)
  • ğŸ”„ Rewrite queries for better execution plans
  • ğŸ’¡ Avoid functions in WHERE clauses that disable indexes
  • ğŸ§Š Cache results when appropriate
  • ğŸ” Use EXPLAIN to check what MySQL is doing behind the scenes

Bonus: Use Grep to Automate the Hunt

# Profile section
grep -A 10 "# Profile" slow-queries.txt

# High row scan, low return
grep -A 20 "Rows examine.*M" slow-queries.txt

# Filesorts or temp tables
grep -A 10 "Using temporary" slow-queries.txt
grep -A 10 "Using filesort" slow-queries.txt

# Full table scans
grep -A 10 "type: ALL" slow-queries.txt
grep -A 10 "key: NULL" slow-queries.txt

# Lock time issues
grep -A 5 "Lock time.*[0-9]s" slow-queries.txt

TL;DR ğŸ§ 

  • ğŸ” Start with the Profile section
  • ğŸš¨ Look for high response time or bad EXPLAIN signs
  • âš™ï¸ Focus on top 5â€“10 offenders
  • ğŸ”§ Fix indexes, rewrite bad queries, reduce rows examined
  • Slow queries are normal. Staying blind to them isnâ€™t. Learn the patterns, spot the pain points, and chip away at them. Your database â€” and your users â€” will notice.

    Note: While tools like pt-query-digest provide powerful insights, nothing replaces understanding the context in which these queries run. Sometimes, there are valid tradeoffs that justify a â€œslowâ€ query, or cases where taking action could cause more disruption than leaving things as they areâ€”at least for the time being. Use the data to inform your decisions, but donâ€™t skip the thinking part.
